Description: Rim sherd of Chian black-figured Komast pottery chalice; white slip; interior: very narrow reserved band at top of rim, glazed black below; part of lotus flower in added white outline with added red centre above two white bands; exterior: band of single dots between brown bands around rim; below, black-figure decoration consisting of komast (head, right arm and part of chest remaining), to right, turning head to left; incised disc as filling ornament.
Curator's comments: Lemos places this sherd in Group D of the Black Figure Komast Chalices. The chalices in this group mark the beginning of the deterioration of the group. All have a rim pattern and the filling ornament consists of well executed incised discs. Williams argues that the images portrayed on the komast chalices were perhaps representations of komos activities that took place in Chios. The buttock pads exaggerated the dancers’ bottoms. The sakkos worn by many of these komasts as well as the earrings suggest the dancers, who were male, were practicing a form of transvestism. If so, these Chians dancers were precursors of the magodoi or performers who wore women’s clothing, made lewd gestures and performed as female and drunk characters. The gestures of the dancers on the chalices are limited and consist of holding pomegranates, tambourines (or wreaths) and snapping fingers. Such dances may also have been connected to religious festivals and performed after religious feasts. Williams, 1983, 162-3
Bibliographic references: Petrie 1886 / Naukratis. Part I., 1884-85 (pl. V, no. 40)
Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 172, p. 325, no. 1491, pl. 196, no. 1491)
Price 1924 / Pottery of Naukratis (pl. XI) (Bottom row)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1250) (phase 2)
